comments.text:
+Jewkester
Nothing wrong with wanting to like something and be a fan of it, but keep 
in mind that there's a difference between "like/dislike" and "good quality 
/ bad quality." Experienced movie critics exist and are successful because 
they critique the overall film quality of something and try to go beyond 
whether they liked the movie or not.

They suffer from biases, of course, like anyone else, but their job is to 
ignore bias and try to assess individual factors like character, plot, and 
setting, as well as assess how those kind of factors work together to make 
a coherent whole.

It's kind of like being a wine connoisseur; to average drinkers, most wines 
taste good because those same drinkers haven't been heavily exposed to the 
highest qualities of wine. Whereas the connoisseur has spent years 
carefully assessing the tastes of wines of varying qualities and has 
developed a skill for discerning when a wine's quality is high.

That said, I've seen movies that critics rated highly and fans rated 
poorly, moves that critics rated poorly and fans rated highly, and anywhere 
in-between. Sometimes I watch a movie that critics rated highly and it 
bores the hell out of me. And sometimes I watch a movie that audiences 
rated highly and I want to slam my head into something.

Opinions, unfortunately, are never universal, though we'd often like them 
to be.

comments.text:
+Sir Noel 100% agreed. I think the idea for the tornado scene was good, it 
just wasn't executed well. I get it, they need to put Clark in a situation

comments.author: Kal V

comments.text:
I have a few things to say, but I can't really go into all of the points in 
this discussion.

Superman's dad did not have to die. I liked this movie, but that was 
stupid. Superman could have ran at normal speed, grabbed his dad and saved 
him, and took cover. It would have been reasonable and no one would have 
thought he was a super human. That was just the director pulling random 
crap out of his ass to get a dramatic death scene.,

Superman couldn't have prevented the destruction. What could he have done, 
told Zod and his crew "hey guys, can we move this fight to the death away 
from here, we might hurt things." Zod and his crew started the battle. 

I liked the dark atmosphere, it made the movie feel much more relateable 
than the other Superman movies. In the other movies, the world is at stake, 
but everything is all happy and rainbows and sunshine. It's not like that. 
You can't have such a serious situation in a bright movie. It just feels 
weird to me.
comments.author: Sir Noel

comments.text:
+SAEB 1) Just b/c a movie is comedic doesn't give it any leeway in the 
realm of reality. Some things realism just can't fix completely, like the 
ability for a man to fly or a billionaire convinced that the best way to 
fight crime is to become a vigilante.

2) To each their own, though I already admitted it was OTT.

3) You literally just admitted that I was right. Hitting a planet will only 
draw the necessary particles IF IT HAS THEM. And you'll need a shitton of 
them in order to completely change a planet's infrastructure, so no, it 
doesn't matter if Mars has some ice.

4) I felt like they did, but to each their own. The fact is, a superhero 
film (especially the origin) has to focus on a lotta different aspects, and 
filmmakers tend to be happy with cutting low on the romantic part. There 
are some exceptions like Superman II and Spider-Man 2, but it is rare.

5) It is a movie cliche for the heroine to provide comfort to the hero in 
their time of sorrow. She was brought onto the ship b/c Zod wanted 
collateral for the army.

6) It does if you're holding a double standard. The only character that 
needs character development IN A SUPERMAN MOVIE, is Superman. Though it was 
nice of them to give Lois and Colonel Hardy some as well.

7) The only time he threw someone through a building was Zod through a 
GAS-FILLED silo in the beginning. Everytime else was someone else throwing 
him.

8) He didn't even technically beat Nam-Ek and Faora in the beginning. Faora 
got her atmosphere filter broken so that missile knocked her out, and 
Nam-Ek actually threw a train at Superman before taking Faora away.

9) I guess that's true, but he either way had no real choice and Zod was 
appearing peacefully.

10) That's what it's always been. In some cases, the glasses change his eye 
color too. It's a disguise that only works in the comics lol, though I felt 
Christopher Reeve did a great job really making the two personas appear as 
two distinct people.
comments.author: Red Rider

comments.text:
+Red Rider
1) I started my statements with, that this film wanted to be more serious 
and dark than the previous films. which doesn't allow it the exceptions 
that the previous films had.
Though you are somewhat right in this regard.

2) That Mr. Kent had to die is acceptable, it is the way that he died that 
was stupid.

3) The world engine can terraform any planet (the energy it hits the earth 
with changes the planets mass and the smoke it releases contains the 
particles necessary for a kryptonian atmosphere).
they needed the Codex because it held the genetical template for the 
kryptonian people, which they need to repopulate the terraformed planet.

4) Iron man and Batman Begins didn't have a rushed romantic relationship, 
since in both parts they were long time friends that were attracted to each 
other. Captain america contained many time skips in which their 
relationship could have been built on.

5) no it is not a movie cliché.´for Lois to possess teleporting powers or 
to be invited into Zods ship,

6) Whether other films have greater or worse character development bears no 
importance in this discussion.

7) yes he saved the planet and that was great, however did he need to keep 
throwing the bad guys into buildings and risk innocent people?

8) Power lifters are stronger than than almost anyone, however I'll vote on 
the mma fighter will win in a fight. Being fast and strong is useful 
however combat training is more useful than that.
However Your argument is plausible enough for me to accepts it.

9) Jor-El still knew Zod, which would give insight to the type of person he 
is.
Though if the purpose was moral support I'll accept the visit to the priest 
if he at least visited virtual dad afterwards.

10) reference to my first statement, also recently read All-Star Superman 
where his Clark Kent disguise relied on more than his glasses (completely 
different posture, unkempt hairstyle covering his face and large clothes 
that makes him look chubby)
And the glasses disguise has always annoyed me, I was hoping that they 
would have added something more in this film (like in all-star superman).

- Cheers
comments.author: RealisticAndOptimistic

comments.text:
+SAEB 1) Because the source material dictates that they have to die for 
Superman's story to begin. If you're gonna bitch about it here than you 
have to bitch about it in EVERY media incarnation of Superman.

2) The death scene was necessary. A little OTT, but Kevin Costner deserves 
a proper send off since his career is practically over lol.

3) Idiot, you clearly weren't paying attention to the film. They spent over 
20 years searching for a new planet, but couldn't rebuild Krypton anyway 
without the codex that contained the genetic code of the entire planet. And 
terraforming doesn't magically turn nothing into something- you have to 
have the right materials, like water, air, atmosphere, good soil.... aka 
Earth.

4) I agree, but it was also rushed/forced in Iron Man, Captain America, 
Batman Begins, and Thor so you're just holding a double standard.

5) It's a movie cliche, deal with it.

6) Disagree completely. Had more character development than most Marvel 
films and character development isn't even synonymous with good so I don't 
get what you're trying to prove with this statement.

7) He prevented an entire planet from being destroyed so I don't know what 
you're complaining about here.

8) It's clearly stated that he soaked in the Earth's sun longer so his 
strength, speed, and control are greater.

9) Jor-El didn't know what Zod wanted until he got plugged into the ship 
and accessed all the Kryptonian files. Either way, Clark was there more for 
moral guidance than anything else.

10) Again, another thing that is tied to the source material and every 
other adaptation. Bitch about it here you bitch about it everywhere.

Funny, that last sentence is exactly how I felt about Avengers.
comments.author: Red Rider

comments.text:
Lets start with a conclusion: this film wanted to be more realistic and 
'dark' than the previous Superman films. this automatically prevents it 
from being allowed to exhibit certain irrational/unrealistic scenarios. 
Which gives the first SM films more leeway.

- Why didn't The Kryptonian race save itself? They can manipulate energy 
into matter, how come they aren't able to predict/measure this outcome and 
create contingencies.

- The dichotomy that is Jonathan Kent and his unnecessary death scene. This 
is the person that shapes Clarks morals and ethics, he is too important to 
half ass.

- Zod's was created/born to preserve Krypton, yet he makes an enemy of the 
only person that could stop him because he isn't willing to move his 
atmosphere changing machine to another planet. Not to mention that this 
unnecessarily made enemy has a an 'object' crucial for saving the 
Kryptonian race.

- Though the actor/actress that play Clark and Lois have chemistry, the 
'love story' is rushed and forced.

- Lois Lane inexplicably being everywhere the script demands her to be.

- Lack of character development.

- The amount of collateral damage that Superman could have prevented.

- Clark wins against Zod and his people (bred and trained warriors) even 
though he possesses no experience in combat. (not even school brawls, since 
a sneeze from him will tear the skin off any human being) 

- Clark asks for guidance from a priest when his digital father could have 
explained everything; who Zod is, what he wants, how to stop him.

- Unless Clarks glasses possess some kind of alien technology that prevents 
facial recognition software or peoples ability to perceive him correctly, 
they shouldn't be able to hide his identity.

I don't know if other people had the same problems as I had, these are 
however the faults that annoyed me.
Still MoS was an acceptable cinematic experience even though it could have 
been much more.
comments.author: RealisticAndOptimistic
